questions.question: What is a constructor?
questions.answer: A special method that initializes objects
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special method automatically called when an object is created. It has the same name as the class and is used to initialize the object's state.

questions.question: Can a constructor have a return type?
questions.answer: No, constructors don't have return types
questions.explanation: Constructors do not have return types, not even void. They implicitly return the newly created object instance.

questions.question: What is a default constructor?
questions.answer: A constructor with no parameters provided by the compiler if no constructor is defined
questions.explanation: A default constructor is a no-argument constructor automatically provided by the compiler if no constructors are explicitly defined in the class.

questions.question: What is a parameterized constructor?
questions.answer: A constructor that accepts parameters to initialize object with specific values
questions.explanation: A parameterized constructor is a constructor that accepts one or more parameters, allowing objects to be initialized with specific values upon creation.

questions.question: What is constructor overloading?
questions.answer: Having multiple constructors with different parameter lists in the same class
questions.explanation: Constructor overloading is having multiple constructors in a class with different parameter lists (different number or types of parameters), providing flexibility in object creation.

questions.question: What is a copy constructor?
questions.answer: A constructor that creates a new object as a copy of an existing object
questions.explanation: A copy constructor creates a new object by copying the values from an existing object of the same class. It takes a reference to an object of the same class as a parameter.

questions.question: What is constructor chaining?
questions.answer: Calling one constructor from another constructor in the same or parent class
questions.explanation: Constructor chaining is the process of calling one constructor from another constructor using 'this()' (same class) or 'super()' (parent class) to avoid code duplication.

questions.question: What is a destructor?
questions.answer: A special method called when an object is destroyed to release resources
questions.explanation: A destructor is a special method called automatically when an object is destroyed or goes out of scope. It's used for cleanup operations like releasing resources (used in C++, not in Java which uses garbage collection).

questions.question: Can you call a constructor explicitly like a regular method?
questions.answer: No, constructors are automatically called during object creation
questions.explanation: Constructors cannot be called explicitly like regular methods. They are automatically invoked during object creation using the 'new' keyword.

questions.question: What happens if you define a constructor in a class?
questions.answer: The compiler will not provide a default constructor
questions.explanation: Once you define any constructor in a class, the compiler will not provide a default no-argument constructor. You must explicitly define it if needed.
